title: How to Clean Belly Button Lint

steps.title: Make a salt solution.
steps.content: Make a salt solution. It's best to clean out your belly button using a salt solution. Mix a teaspoon of table salt into a cup of water. Mix the salt in until it dissolves. [1] X Research source Before cleaning your belly button, take a quick shower. This will help loosen up any dirt or lint in your belly button.

steps.title: Massage your belly button with the solution.
steps.content: Massage your belly button with the solution. You can use your fingers or a small rag to clean your belly button. If you use your fingers, wash your hands first. Dip your rag or fingers into the salt solution. [2] X Research source Gently massage the inside of your belly button. This will loosen up any lint or other dirt and debris. If some pieces of lint are very large, you may have to pull them out of your belly button.

steps.title: Rinse and dry your belly button when you're done.
steps.content: Rinse and dry your belly button when you're done. Do this using plain water. Gently pat dry the area around your belly button dry with a clean rag.

steps.title: Consult a doctor if you have a belly button infection.
steps.content: Consult a doctor if you have a belly button infection. Belly button infections can happen due to poor hygiene or a recent piercing. You should see a doctor as soon as you can in the event of an infection. Signs of a belly button infection include: [3] X Research source Red or itchy skin near the belly button Swelling A bad smell Discharge from the belly button Pain or blistering around the belly button

steps.title: Gather your supplies.
steps.content: Gather your supplies. You don't want to keep your infant waiting to be cleaned. A baby may become fussy or uncomfortable if cleaning takes too long. When you get ready to clean an infant's belly button, get your supplies ready ahead of time. You will need the following: [4] X Research source A large towel for your baby to lie on. A sponge, cotton swabs, a bowl of warm water, and baby soap.

steps.title: Wash your hands.
steps.content: Wash your hands. Babies are prone to infection. Wash your hands under warm water using soap before you begin the process of cleaning your baby's belly button. [5] X Research source Wash your hands for about 20 seconds. Make sure to dry your hands off using a clean cloth or paper towel.

steps.title: Check for infection.
steps.content: Check for infection. A belly button infection can be dangerous for an infant. If you notice an infection, your baby will need to see a pediatrician as soon as possible. The following are the signs of a belly button infection in a baby: [6] X Research source Discharge around the belly button A foul smell coming from the umbilical cord Tenderness or swelling of the skin

steps.title: Wash the cord.
steps.content: Wash the cord. Dab a piece of cloth in warm water. Gently wipe down the umbilical cord and the surrounding area. Then, wipe down the cord with a mild cleanser. [7] X Research source You want to keep the cord clean and dry until it falls off naturally. This keeps your baby's belly button free of infection. Do not use rubbing alcohol to clean an umbilical cord.

steps.title: Dry the cord.
steps.content: Dry the cord. Leaving the cord wet could result in an infection. Gently pat the cord, and the surrounding area, dry with a clean, absorbent cloth. Make sure the cord and the surrounding skin are dry to the touch. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Shave the hair around your navel.
steps.content: Shave the hair around your navel. Your belly button will be less prone to lint if there's less hair around your navel. If you grow hair around your navel, shaving may prevent lint from building up. If belly button lint bothers you, try shaving your navel with a razor and see if you notice a reduction in lint. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Wear older clothes when possible.
steps.content: Wear older clothes when possible. Lint collects in your belly button because of fibers of fabric, like cotton, coming off your clothes. Older clothing may attract less lint than new clothes because it's already shed those fibers of fabric. When possible, wear old clothes to prevent the accumulation of belly button lint. [10] X Research source If you don't have anywhere special to go on a given day, throw on an old t-shirt.

steps.title: Avoid moisturizing your belly button.
steps.content: Avoid moisturizing your belly button. Do not use lotions or moisturizers in or near your belly button. While these are generally safe to use on other parts of the body, extra moisture near the belly button is dangerous. It can encourage fungal or bacterial infections. [11] X Research source
